Australia will take 12,000 refugees How the world is reacting Refugee crisis: full coverage Don't care about the growing refugee crisis? You may care that the issue is increasingly intruding on domestic politics not only in Europe but also in Australia and the United States.
The increase in refugees, asylum seekers and forcibly displaced people to the highest level since the end of World War II represents a "significant political risk" in international politics, according to research from international banking group Citi.
The migrant issue will be on the political agenda for some time. Pictured:A Berlin fireman blows balloons made from latex gloves for migrant children who had arrived on a train from Munich. Photo: Getty
What is worrying is that the flow of refugees, driven by the Syrian conflict, "merges" national politics with broader "geopolitical" risks.
Advertisement In other words, what happens in the Syrian War – now in its fifth year – and in Iraq, Libya, and Afghanistan is beginning to sway the domestic agendas of countries like Australia, France, Germany and Britain.
"In our view the refugee crisis is not a temporary flashpoint; instead, addressing flows of human beings will likely move to the top of the political agenda in many countries and stay there for an extended period," the reports' authors write.
Europe-bound: Thousands of migrants have used the so-called 'Balkans route' in their trek to Europe and to the political agendas of the West. Photo: Getty
Immigration is "increasingly prominent and often controversial feature of the political debate in the US, Australia, and elsewhere, influencing public opinion, electoral politics and policymaking," the report says.
Elections in France and Germany in 2017 and the US in 2016 may be in play, where candidates like Donald Trump capitalise on anti-immigrant sentiments.
Last year, nearly 60 million people were displaced, the most recorded, led by Syrians, who have been streaming out of the war-torn country, according to the UN.
Migrants make their way through Serbia, near the town of Subotica, on their way to Germany. Photo: Getty
Just this week, Prime Minister Tony Abbott announced plans to accept 12,000 asylum seekers from Syria and provide aid for additional refugees. At the same time, the nation will start air strikes in Syria in the battle against Islamic State.
Rising fears for immigration challenge the notion of the free movement of people, money and goods. While immigration is needed in countries with ageing and declining populations, it remains "deeply unpopular politically" potentially triggering a move to wind back economic globalisation, Citi said.
"Will the politics of reinstating barriers and controls trump the economics of globalisation?" the report asks. It describes "public attitudes and policymakers' responses to the refugee and migration crisis" as another bellwether of a "wider post-crisis backlash towards globalisation".
Europe has already seen the rise of anti-immigrant, anti-EU parties such as UKIP in Britain, France's National Front, nationalist party Jobbik in Hungary. But it's not limited to Europe. "Opposition to immigration has contributed to the rise in Donald Trump's favourability ratings in his candidacy for US president."
Australia like European nations must also contend with radicalised citizens who have gone to Syria and Iraq to fight and who pose a threat on their return.
This international trend feeds fears surrounding immigration, along with competition for jobs, and the effect on a local communities, that help fuel anti-immigrant movements and parties.
Australian National University Strategic and Defence Studies Centre senior fellow John Blaxland said the knock-on consequences of the refugee crisis for domestic politics in the advanced democracies are difficult to predict.
In Europe, the "greatest concern is the challenge to the EU's sense of self-identity and how it perceives its own security and the integrity of its borders," he said.
This is particularly true, he said, given the "growing inability to control its borders".
"The implications are hard to fathom but there are numerous ominous indicators that Europe is on the cusp of an existential crisis."
